Photothermal technology offers distinct advantages for catalytic CO2 methanation. Herein, we synthesized a series of Ni-based catalysts (denoted as TiO2-x/Ni-X) through controlled calcination of NiTi-layered double hydroxides (LDHs) precursors at 400–700°C. In a continuous-flow system under xenon lamp irradiation (3.2 W/cm²), the TiO2-x /Ni-X catalysts exhibited a reduction temperature dependent CH4 production rate. During 40-hour stability testing, the optimized TiO2-x/Ni-550 catalyst achieved a sustained CH4 production rate of 180 mmol gcat −1 h−1 with a remarkable near-unity selectivity (>99 %), and the light irradiation substantially enhanced the CH4 yield compared to bare thermal catalysis. Comprehensive structural characterization and mechanistic studies revealed competing roles governing catalytic activity, with TiO2-x/Ni-550 demonstrating an optimal balance for CH4 generation kinetics. Graphical Abstract TiO2-x/Ni-X catalysts were prepared through controlled calcination of NiTi- LDHs for photothermal CO2 methanation with a sustained CH4 production rate of 180 mmol gcat −1 h−1 and a selectivity above 99 %. Keywords Photothermal catalysis CO₂ methanation Layered double hydroxides Near-unity selectivity Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The immense energy demands of modern human society necessitate massive consumption of fossil fuels, thereby generating enormous CO2 emission [1]. This trend is still accelerating, and as a result, the capture and conversion of CO2 has gained a lot of attention on a global scale [2]. Among various target products, CH4 represents an ideal reduction product due to its valuable features: (1) direct utilization for heat generation, (2) deployment as a feedstock for synthesizing higher-value chemicals, and (3) capacity for hydrogen storage [3–5]. Converting CO2 into CH4 through methanation delivers economic benefits and concurrently mitigates the greenhouse effect [6,7]. However, the methanation of CO2 presents significant challenges due to the intrinsic thermodynamic stability of the CO2 molecule [8–10]. In conventional thermal catalysis, CO2 methanation typically requires elevated temperatures or high pressures, inevitably causing significant energy consumption [11]. Alternatively, photocatalysis harnesses clean solar energy to drive reactions under mild conditions [12]. Nevertheless, the efficiency of photocatalytic CO2 methanation is very low due to the low light absorption efficiency and rapid recombination of photo-generated charge carriers [13]. To address these limitations, a large number of researchers has focused on the study of photothermal catalysis. [14] Compared to photocatalytic and thermal CO2 methanation, photothermal technology has shown much higher activity even under mild conditions. Ye et al. pioneered the application of Group VIII metals in photothermal CO2 methanation in 2014 [15]. Subsequently, extensive research has established photothermal catalysis as a promising approach for enhancing CO2 conversion efficiency, owing to its exceptional catalytic performance and effective solar energy utilization [16]. Among developed catalysts, Zhong Jin and his colleagues engineered a Rhodium/Alumina (Rh/Al) nanoantenna photothermal catalyst that achieved near 100 % CH4 selectivity with a production rate of 550 mmol g−1 h−1 under focused simulated sunlight irradiation (11.3 W/cm2) [17]. However, the high cost of noble metal catalysts hampers their large-scale commercialization [18]. Consequently, developing cost-effective catalysts for efficient photothermal CO2 methanation holds considerable practical significance. Within this context, Ni-based catalysts have garnered significant interest due to their catalytic performance, cost-effectiveness, and exceptional promise for industrial-scale implementation [19]. For instance, Jing Chen and co-workers fabricated a metal-organic framework (MOF)-derived Ni-based catalyst (50Ni/ZrO2) that delivered a stable, high-efficiency CH4 production rate of 583.3 mmol g−1 h−1 with notably high selectivity (95 %) during extended stability testing under 2.9 W/cm2 illumination [20]. The rational construction of Ni catalysts is a promising strategy for efficient photothermal CO2 methanation, yet remains challenging. Recently, layered double hydroxides (LDHs) have been employed as a precursor for synthesizing well-dispersed metal catalysts. This is because when LDH materials are calcined under a reducing atmosphere or in air, they undergo a topotactic transformation, forming homogeneously dispersed metal nanoparticles (NPs) supported on a metal oxide substrate [21,22]. Herein, we synthesized a series of Ni-based photothermal catalysts (denoted as TiO2-x/Ni-X, where X represents reduction temperature) via thermal reduction of NiTi-LDH precursors under H2 atmosphere at 400–700°C. Under continuous flow conditions, TiO2-x/Ni-550 exhibited exceptional stability throughout a 40-hour reaction period, maintaining a consistent methane production rate of 180 mmol gcat −1 h−1 with a remarkable near-unity selectivity (>99 %) of CH4 product, while demonstrating substantially enhanced activity under illumination compared to thermal catalysis alone. Detailed structural characterization and mechanistic studies revealed that along with the increasing of reduction temperature of TiO2-x/Ni-X catalysts, the enhanced light absorption ability, the increased equilibrium temperature, the increased separation efficiency of photogenerated charge carriers, the increased Ni0 species, the decreased CO2 absorption ability and the decreased amount of exposed Ni sites play competitive roles in the photothermal CO2 hydrogenation reaction, and the optimized CH4 evolution rate is achieved over TiO2-x/Ni-550 catalyst. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals All chemicals were used as received without further purification. Urea was purchased from Aladdin, TiCl4 was purchased from Damas-beta, and Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. HCl (36 wt%) was obtained from Hangzhou Shuanglin Chemical Reagent Factory. Deionized water was employed throughout the experiments. 2.2 Sample preparation Urea decomposition method was used to prepare the samples according to previous reports [23]. Specifically, a solution was prepared by dissolving Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O (0.006 mol), HCl (0.25 mL), TiCl4 (0.25 mL), and urea (0.1 mol) in deionized water (100 mL). The mixture was stirred at 95 °C for 24 h. The resulting solid was collected by centrifugation, thoroughly washed, and dried overnight at 60 °C. The NiTi-LDH nanosheets were subsequently calcined in a muffle furnace at 500 °C for 4 h under static air, employing a heating rate of 2 °C min−1, to yield the mixed metal oxide (NiTi-MMO, a composite of NiO and TiO2). The obtained NiTi-MMO was then reduced in a H2/Ar (10:90, v/v) gas flow (70 mL min−1) for 4 h at temperatures of 400 °C, 550 °C and 700 °C (heating rate: 2 °C min−1). The resulting catalysts were designated as TiO2-x/Ni-400, TiO2-x/Ni-550, and TiO2-x/Ni-700, respectively. 2.3 Characterizations Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer and XRD scanning rate was 0.6 s/Step. Raman spectroscopy was performed using a Thermo Scientific DXR3 confocal microscope with 532 nm laser excitation. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) imaging and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping were conducted on a JEOL JEM-2100F field-emission microscope. The light absorption ability of samples was recorded on UV-3600. The CO2 Temperature Programmed Desorption was recoded on AutoChem1 II 2920. nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm was recorded on Micromeritics 3Flex. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was carried out on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha+ spectrometer and XPS data were calibrated to 284.8 eV using a reference C1s peak. Photoelectrochemical measurements (photocurrent response and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy) were acquired in a three-electrode configuration using a Chenhua CHI 760E workstation with 0.5 M Na2SO4 electrolyte, employing a Pt wire counter electrode and Ag/AgCl reference electrode. In situ Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectra collected on a JASCO FT-IR-6300 spectrometer and the resolution of DRIFTS was better than 0.4 cm−1. 2.4 Catalytic activity evaluation CO2 photothermal methanation was conducted in a continuous-flow microreactor system (CEL-GPPCM, Beijing China Education Au-light Technology Co., Ltd.) under atmospheric pressure. The quartz reactor tube was sequentially packed with Quartz wool, 200 mg quartz sand diluent and 20 mg catalyst bed. Prior to illumination, the system was purged in situ for 2 h by a 20 mL min−1 reaction gas mixture (CO2:H2:Ar = 15:60:25) to eliminate residual atmospheric components. The methanation reaction proceeded at 10 mL min−1 total flow rate. A 300 W xenon lamp (CEL-PF300-T6) was used light source. Local light intensity at the catalyst bed was measured using an optical power meter (CEL-NP2000–2(10)A), while surface temperatures were monitored by thermocouples. Reaction products were quantified by gas chromatography (Agilent 8860). The selectivity of CH4 (%) = [ CH 4 ] [ CH 4 ] + [ CO ] Here, [CH₄] and [CO] represent the yield of CH4 or CO. 3 Results and discussion Reduction of NiTi-MMO in H2 atmosphere at 400, 550 and 700 ℃, respectively, affords TiO2-x/Ni-X samples, where X refers to the reduction temperature. The structural and morphological characteristics of TiO2-x/Ni-X are analyzed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). As shown in Fig. 1, Ni nanoparticles (NPs) reduced at different temperatures are dispersed in the TiO2-x matrix at high density. Ni NPs are covered by TiO2-x, which is one of the classical features of the Strong Metal-Support Interaction effect (SMSI) [24]. H2-TPR experiment were conducted to further demonstrate the formation of the SMSI effect, with specific results shown in Figure S1. The hydrogen consumption peak at 360 °C is assigned to the reduction of surface NiO species with weak metal-support interactions. The main reduction peak observed at 489 °C is attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed NiO species strongly interacting with TiO2 [25]. Evidently, there exists an SMSI effect between the metal nanoparticles and the anatase support. In general, the TiO2-x/Ni-X samples exhibit similar morphology. The average particle size of Ni NPs increases slightly from ∼20.3 nm to ∼23.3 nm when the reduction temperature is increased from 400 to 700 ℃. Previous report illustrated that the growth of Ni NPs was inhibited by the SMSI effect, which could explain the similar average size of Ni NPs [26,27]. Here, Ni NPs are mainly presented as (111) crystalline surfaces with a crystal spacing of 0.202 nm, and TiO2 shows a typical (101) crystalline surface with a lattice spacing of 0.35 nm. It is clear that in TiO2-x/Ni-400, NiO (200) crystal plane with a crystal plane distance of 0.210 nm is observed. This may be due to the fact that the temperature of the reduction process is not high enough, which leads to the incomplete reduction of NiO in 400 ℃. The microstructure and compositional distribution are characterized by high-angle annular darkfield scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) and the elemental mapping analysis, and the results are shown in Figure S2. Obvious agglomeration of Ni NPs is observed due to excessive Ni loading. Additionally, elemental distribution analysis provides direct evidence for the presence of the SMSI effect, as shown in Figure S3. The Ni nanoparticles are encapsulated by the support, which is a characteristic feature of the SMSI effect. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the materials are shown in Fig. 2 a. A series of diffraction peaks are observed in the NiTi-LDH precursor, appearing at 2θ = 11.7 °, 23.2 °, 34.7 °, 38.9 ° and 60.8 °. These peaks are characteristic of the NiTi- LDH phase and are assigned to the (003), (006), (012), (015) and (110) crystal planes, respectively [28]. The TEM image of NiTi-LDH is shown in Figure S4. As clearly observed, the NiTi-LDH exhibits a nanosheet morphology. Upon calcination in air, the LDH is transformed into a mixed metal oxide phase (NiTi-MMO), and the weak diffraction peak at 2θ= 25.4° is attributed to (101) crystal plane of anatase TiO2 (JCPDS 21–1272). The diffraction peaks at 37.3°, 43.5°, 63.1° and 75.9° are attributed to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) crystal planes of face-centered cubic NiO (JCPDS 47–1049), respectively [29]. All TiO2-x/Ni-X samples exhibit characteristic peaks of anatase TiO2 phase (JCPDS 21–1272) peaks with metallic Ni phase (JCPDS 04–0850). The XRD peaks of the metallic Ni are located at 44.8°, 52.0° and 76.6° with indexes of (111), (200) and (220), respectively. At the same time, the characteristic peaks of fcc NiO (2θ=37.3°, 43.5° and 63.1°) are also observed in TiO2-x/Ni-400, and all the samples maintain similar Ni particle sizes according to the Scherrer equation (shown in Table 1). These results are consistent with the TEM characterization. Raman spectroscopy is utilized to further investigate the structural characteristics of catalysts and the results are shown in Fig. 1 b. The Raman peak at 145 cm−1 is attributed to the Eg vibrational mode of anatase, which is consistent with the XRD results. The Eg mode corresponds mainly to the symmetric stretching vibration of the O-Ti-O bond [30]. As the reduction temperature increases, the Eg peak (∼145 cm−1) is shifted to the high wave number side. Such shift of the Raman peak is attributed to the formation of oxygen vacancies or lattice defects in TiO2 [31]. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm is shown in Fig. 2 c. All samples belong to the IV isotherms with the H3-type hysteresis loops, which implies the presence of irregular mesoporous structures [32]. The width of the hysteresis loops is affected by the reduction temperature and decreases with increasing reduction temperature. The SBET, pore volume, and average pore size of the samples are listed in Table 1. It is clear that these parameters are significantly related to the reduction temperature. The SBET decreases from 151.3 m2/g to 25.9 m2/g and a similar trend appears in the pore volume change when the reduction temperature is increased from 400° to 700°, which is caused by the collapse of the pore structure and the increase of particle size [33]. At the same time, the average pore size increases from 22.6 nm to 38.0 nm, which is attributed to the breakup of mesoporous structure under high temperature conditions to change the pore distribution (Figure S5). In order to characterize the surface chemistry and interactions of nickel metal nanoparticles and anatase TiO2, XPS analysis is used and the results are shown in Fig. 2d-f, and the specific peak messages are presented in Table S2. Fig. 2d shows the Ni 2p spectra of TiO2-x/Ni-X samples. The peaks located at 852.3, 855.7, and 861.1 eV belong to Ni0, Ni2+, and satellite peak, respectively [34]. The presence of Ni2+ is due to the oxidation by air and the incomplete reduction by hydrogen [35]. When the reduction temperature is increased from 400 to 700℃, the intensity of the Ni0 species peak increases, indicating that more amount of NiO is reduced to Ni0, which is in keeping with the results described previously. The electronic binding energies of Ni0, Ni2+ and satellite peaks are shifted towards lower binding, indicating a more negative Ni electronic valence, which is related to the enhancement of the metal-carrier interaction [26,36]. Moreover, the absence of Ni0 peak in TiO2-x/Ni-400 may be due to the fact that the amount of surface-exposed Ni0 is very small. The Ti 2p spectra are shown in Fig. 2e. For the TiO2-x/Ni-400 sample, the peaks at 458.8 and 464.6 eV belong to the Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2 orbitals of Ti4+, respectively, and the peaks at 458.2 and 463.9 eV belong to the Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2 orbitals of Ti3+, respectively [37,38]. The appearance of Ti3+ is attributed to the introduction of surface defects [39]. An obvious fact is that from TiO2-x/Ni-400 to TiO2-x/Ni-700, the Ti3+ occupancy ratio is increased, which implies the enhancement of oxygen vacancies. During hydrogen reduction, both NiO and TiO2 are reduced, resulting in the formation of metallic Ni and Ti3+. Subsequently, due to the strong metal-support interaction effect, electron transfer occurs from TiO2 to Ni metal particles, which increases the electron density of Ni and consequently causes a shift of the Ni 2p spectrum toward lower binding energy, which is consistent with a previous report [26]. The O 1 s spectrum, shown in Fig. 2f, exhibits three peaks at approximately 532.7 eV, 531.6 eV, and 530 eV, which are assigned to surface chemisorption oxygen (OC), oxygen vacancies (OV), and lattice oxygen (OL), respectively [37,40]. When the reduction temperature increases, the percentage of OV increases, implying an increase in oxygen vacancies, which is in agreement with Raman results. In order to obtain detailed information about the environment of nickel and its electronic interactions with the anatase lattice, the X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) of the Ni K-edge is investigated, and the results are shown in Fig. 3a. TiO2-x/Ni-400 shows a strong white line (at ∼ 8350.5 eV) in contrast to Ni foil, while the curve of this catalyst at 8337 eV locates between the curves of Ni foil (8832 eV) and NiO (8842 eV), suggesting that the average valence state of Ni is between 0 and + 2 [41]. This finding indicates the coexistence of metallic Ni and NiO phases in TiO2-x/Ni-400, which is in agreement with above characterization results. The XANES spectrum of TiO2-x/Ni-550 is close to that of Ni foil, which indicates that Ni exists mainly as metallic Ni in this catalyst. Notably, the Ni absorption edge of the TiO2-x/Ni-700 catalyst shifts toward lower energies than the Ni foil, suggesting the presence of Niδ- species with lower valence than the metallic state [23]. According to previous reports, this can be attributed to the transfer of electrons from the support to the metal, which is one of the classical SMSI effects [42,43]. Furthermore, this electron enrichment promotes the transfer of electrons to CO2, and according to molecular orbital theory, electrons populate the antibonding orbitals of CO2. This electron configuration facilitates the activation and dissociation of CO2 [44]. To investigate the coordination environment of Ni, the Ni K-edge Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra is recorded in Fig. 3 b and the fitting results are shown in Figure S6. As shown in Fig. 3 b, all catalysts exhibit a strong peak at approximately 2.14 Å, which is attributed to Ni–Ni coordination [45]. When the reduction temperature is 400 °C, a distinct peak is observed around 2.6 Å, assigned to the Ni–O scattering path [39]. At higher reduction temperatures, the Ni–O coordination disappears, consistent with the observations from our XRD and TEM results. The photothermal CO2 hydrogenation activities of TiO2-x/Ni-X catalyst were investigated in a continuous flow reactor under atmospheric pressure (the experimental setup was shown in Figure S7). The main product is CH4 with trace amount of CO. Fig. 4a displays the CH4 production rate and selectivity of different TiO2-x/Ni-X catalysts under xenon lamp irradiation (3.2 W/cm2). Under these conditions, the catalytic activities follow the order: TiO2-x/Ni-550 > TiO2-x/Ni-400 > TiO2-x/Ni-700. The detailed mechanism of this trend will be discussed later. Furthermore, photo-assisted thermocatalytic CO2 reduction experiments were conducted and the results were shown in Fig. 4b and Table S3. The applied light intensity is only 2.5 mW/cm2, and the equilibrium temperature of the catalysts reaches no more than 60 °C under illumination without external thermal heating, representing an increase of only approximately 30 °C above room temperature. When only illumination is applied, no CH4 generation is observed over all the TiO2-x/Ni-X catalysts (Table S3). This effectively rules out significant thermal effects induced by the illumination itself. Under additional heating to 300 °C in the dark, the activity of the catalysts follows the order: TiO2-x/Ni-550 > TiO2-x/Ni-400 > TiO2-x/Ni-700, with CH4 selectivity exceeding 99 %. Strikingly, upon introducing light illumination, both the activity order and the high CH4 selectivity are maintained. Furthermore, the catalyst activity is substantially enhanced by a factor of 2∼3 compared to the purely thermal catalytic process. These phenomena confirm that light illumination plays an indispensable role in the catalytic process. The specific function of light will be further discussed in subsequent sections. Next, we further investigate the stability of TiO2-x/Ni-550 catalyst. A 40-hour CO2 hydrogenation durability test was conducted under xenon lamp irradiation (3.2 W/cm2), as shown in Fig. 4 c. The CH4 production rate increases during the initial 5 h, then the CH4 production rate stabilizes at approximately 180 mmol gcat -1 h-1. Moreover, the CH4 selectivity remains stable, consistently exceeding 99 %. Characterizations by XRD and Raman spectroscopy (Figure S8 and S9) reveal no significant changes between the spent TiO2-x/Ni-550 catalyst and its fresh counterpart, confirming the structural stability of TiO2-x/Ni-550 after the reaction. The XPS analysis is shown in Figure S10, the proportions of Ni0 and Ti3+ in the post-reaction sample are increased, which is attributed to the inevitable reduction of the catalyst under the reducing atmosphere during photothermal reaction. Additionally, TEM image of the spent sample is presented in Figure S11. No carbon deposition nor significant morphological changes in the catalyst are observed compared to the fresh catalyst. Fig. 4d shows the catalyst activity and surface temperature as a function of light intensity. The CH4 production rates increase as the light intensity increases, and 113.2 mmol gcat -1 h-1 production of CH4 is obtained over TiO2-x/Ni-550 under the maximum light intensity of 3.2 W/cm2 in the first hour, and then the activity stabilizes at approximately 180 mmol gcat -1 h-1, which is superior to some other earth-abundant metal-based catalysts for photothermal CO2 hydrogenation under similar reaction conditions (Table S4). The reaction kinetics of CO2 methanation over the TiO2-x/Ni-550 catalyst was investigated under both dark and illuminated conditions (light intensity of 2.5 mW/cm2) within a temperature range of 200∼350 °C (Fig. 4e). The apparent activation energy is calculated by fitting the measured reaction rate (r) to the Arrhenius equation (lnr = -Eₐ/RT + lnA). As shown in Fig. 4f, the apparent activation energy for TiO2-x/Ni-550 under dark conditions is 73.57 kJ/mol, which is decreased to 63.35 kJ/mol upon illumination. This suggests that light facilitates the activation of reactants, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity. In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in-situ DRIFTS) is employed to gain deeper insights into the CO2 hydrogenation reaction on the catalyst, the results are presented in Fig. 5 a. Table S5 summarizes the infrared band distribution of the surface-active substances. Upon introducing the reaction gases (CO2 and H2) over the TiO2-x/Ni-550 catalyst, a broad absorption band located at 2335 cm-1 is observed, which is attributed to the absorption of CO2 molecules in the infrared region. Upon heating from 20 to 300 °C, multiple absorption bands in the infrared spectra are observed, and the intensity increases with the increasing temperature. Upon heating to 250 °C, the peaks emerging in the 1900–2100 cm-1 region are attributed to surface-adsorbed carbonyl species [36]. Thus, it is proposed that CH4 formation over the TiO2-x/Ni-550 catalyst proceeds via a hydrogen-assisted CO dissociation pathway. Additionally, no discernible peaks assignable to gaseous CO molecules (2100–2200 cm-1) were observed in the infrared spectra [36]. This absence suggests minimal CO generation in the reaction system, demonstrating the catalyst’s high selectivity toward methane formation over CO. The peaks observed at 2933 cm-1 and 2855 cm-1 are assigned to the symmetric stretching vibrations of CH2* and CH3* species, respectively [46]. These surface intermediates are identified as pivotal species in the methane formation pathway. The peaks at 3016 cm-1 and 1304 cm-1 are assigned to CH4, attributed to C–H stretching vibrations [47]. The CH4 peaks are not observed below 250 °C due to its low concentration, which falls below the instrument’s detection limit. As critical intermediates for the CO2-to-CH4 transformation, vibrational modes of surface methoxy (H3CO*) are observed at 1040 and 1123 cm-1, while formyl species (HCO*) exhibit characteristic bands at 1080 cm-1 in the infrared spectra [48,49]. The vibrational bands observed at 1582, 1265,1400, and 1643 cm-1 are attributed to surface formate species (HCOO*), which is identified as a key intermediate in the formation of carbonaceous products and underwent further transformation to adsorbed CO (CO*) [36,46,49,50]. The absorption bands positioned at 1541 and 1473 cm-1 are attributed to monodentate carbonate species (m-CO3 2-), which originates from the bonding of CO2 molecules with surface oxygen atoms of the catalyst [36,49]. Based on the critical spectroscopic evidence presented herein and corroborated by established literature [48], we make a conclusion that the CO2 hydrogenation reaction path could be as follows: (1) CO2+e-+ *+H+ → HCOO* (2) HCOO*+e-+H+ → CO*+H2O (3) CO*+e-+H+ →HCO* (4) HCO*+e-+H+ →H2CO* (5) H2CO*+e-+H+ → H3CO* (6) H3CO*+e-+H+ → CH4+O* Meanwhile, reactions (7) and (8) are inevitable. (7) H2CO* → CH2*+O (8) H3CO* → CH3*+O * Denotes the catalytically active site. The process of CH4 formation is shown in Fig. 6. Under light illumination, photothermal heating on TiO2-x/Ni-X catalyst can trigger CO2 reduction with H2 by increasing the surface temperature. CO2 can be adsorbed on the oxygen vacancy sites of the surface of TiO2-x to form carbonates. The adsorbed H species produced from H2 dissociation on the surface of Ni nanoparticles then spill over to promote the conversion of carbonates to formate species, which further participates in the transformation to methoxy group and finally produces CH4. Moreover, the light-excited charge carriers from TiO2 and hot carriers from Ni nanoparticles not only have the potential of promoting H2 dissociation to H species but also accelerate the formation and conversion of reactive surface intermediates, thereby resulting in the higher CO2 methanation activity compared with pure thermocatalytic reaction. To investigate the effect of light on the CO2 reduction reaction, in-situ DRIFT spectra of TiO2-x/Ni-550 were acquired at 250°C under illumination versus dark conditions (Fig. 5 b). Compared to the dark control, characteristic peaks of pivotal intermediates (HCOO*, CO*, HCO*, CH2*, CH3* and H3CO*) exhibited enhanced intensities under light irradiation. This observation demonstrated that illumination promoted CO2 methanation by accelerating the formation and conversion of reactive surface intermediates [2]. Now we are in a position to reveal the reason why TiO2-x/Ni-550 exhibits higher photothermal activity than that of TiO2-x/Ni-400 and TiO2-x/Ni-700 catalysts. According to XPS results, the Ni⁰ content increases with rising calcination temperature. However, paradoxically, the sample exhibiting the highest Ni⁰ content (TiO2-x/Ni-700) shows the lowest CH4 production rate. We deem that this phenomenon may be the result of a combination of several factors. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms indicate a decrease in the specific surface area of the catalysts with increasing temperature (Fig. 2 c). Furthermore, previous report also indicated that the encapsulation of Ni particles by the support inevitably occurred when increasing the reduction temperature of TiO2/NiO in H2 atmosphere, which would reduce the exposed nickel surface area. Consequently, these factors inevitably leaded to diminished catalytic activity of the TiO2-x/Ni-700 catalyst. Fig. 7 a shows the ultraviolet-visible-near infrared (UV–vis–NIR) absorption spectra of TiO2-x/Ni-X catalysts, which exhibit high absorption across the entire tested spectral range. The strong absorption in the visible to infrared region can be attributed to the localized surface plasmon resonance effect of Ni nanoparticles [51]. The optical absorption capacity of the catalysts followed the order: TiO2-x/Ni-550 ≈ TiO2-x/Ni-700 > TiO2-x/Ni-400. High light absorption leads to increased light energy utilization and enhanced photothermal effect. It is well-known that Ni nanoparticles can act as a “nanoheater” to increase the surface temperature of catalyst via photothermal effect, which contributes to efficient photothermal catalysis and light energy utilization [52]. We further measured the surface temperature of the catalysts under xenon lamp illumination (3.2 W/cm2), as shown in Fig. 7 b. Specifically, the equilibrium temperatures are determined as follows: TiO2-x/Ni-700 (403 °C) ≈ TiO2-x/Ni-550 (401 °C) > TiO2-x/Ni-400 (382 °C). Given the comparable total nickel content in the TiO2-x/Ni-X catalysts, the weaker light absorption capacity and lower surface temperature observed for TiO2-x/Ni-400 may be attributed to the incomplete reduction of NiO during catalyst preparation, which results in residual NiO species that lack localized surface plasmon resonance-a photothermal response characteristic of metallic nickel. This is one of the main reasons that TiO2-x/Ni-550 exhibits higher activity than that of TiO2-x/Ni-400. To elucidate the interaction between the reaction center and reactants, temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) was performed with the results presented in Fig. 7c. Previous studies have confirmed that basicity is a crucial factor influencing TiO2-x/Ni-X samples in the CO2 methanation reaction. This is because adsorbed CO2 can be decomposed into CO* and O* [53]. Subsequently, during CO2 hydrogenation, the cleavage of the C-O bond in formate-derived species such as H2COH*/H3CO* is the key step governing the selective formation of CH4 [36,54,55]. Over the tested temperature range (50–600 oC), the desorption peaks observed between 200 and 500 oC are assigned to medium-strength surface basic sites [56]. The CO2 adsorption capacity of the catalysts progressively decreases with the increasing reduction temperature, specifically declining from 0.77 mmol/g for TiO2-x/Ni-400–0.23 mmol/g for TiO2-x/Ni-700. During photothermal catalytic processes, light irradiation could provide sufficient thermal energy to elevate the catalyst surface temperature, thereby initiating the catalytic reaction [57]. Additionally, photogenerated charges could participate in the reaction, lowering the activation energy barrier and consequently enhancing catalytic activity [58]. Given the semiconductor properties of TiO2, charge carriers would be generated on the catalyst surface under light illumination. Moreover, hot carriers would be also generated on Ni nanoparticles [59]. Transient photocurrent response measurements and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were conducted to verify the critical role of light illumination during the reaction process [60]. As shown in Fig. 8a, under light illumination, photocurrent responses are observed on all catalysts. The photocurrent density followed the order: TiO2-x/Ni-700 > TiO2-x/Ni-550 > TiO2-x/Ni-400. Furthermore, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) Nyquist plot arc radius (Fig. 8b), both in the dark and under illumination, exhibit the trend: TiO2-x/Ni-700 < TiO2-x/Ni-550 < TiO2-x/Ni-400, indicating that TiO2-x/Ni-700 exhibits the smallest charge transfer resistance and displays improved separation efficiency of the photoinduced electron–hole pairs and electronic conductivity. Notably, the arc radius decreases under illumination compared to dark conditions. Therefore, along with the increasing of reduction temperature of TiO2-x/Ni-X catalysts, the enhanced light absorption ability, the increased equilibrium temperature, the increased separation efficiency of photogenerated charge carriers, the increased Ni0 species, the decreased CO2 absorption ability and the decreased amount of exposed Ni sites play competitive roles in the photothermal CO2 hydrogenation reaction, and the optimized CH4 evolution rate is achieved over TiO2-x/Ni-550 catalyst. 4 Conclusion In summary, a series of Ni-based catalysts were successfully synthesized through reduction of NiTi-LDH nanosheet precursors at 400–700 °C for photothermal CO₂ methanation. Among these, the TiO2-x/Ni-550 catalyst demonstrated superior catalytic performance, achieving a CH4 production rate of 180 mmol gcat -1 h-1 with a remarkable near-unity selectivity (>99 %). This catalyst also exhibited exceptional stability, maintaining its activity and structural integrity throughout a 40-hour operation period. Photo-assisted thermocatalytic experiments revealed that photogenerated charge carriers effectively promoted the formation and conversion of key reaction intermediates. Structural characterization and mechanistic studies indicated that the catalytic activity was governed by competing roles. In-situ DRIFTS analysis identified critical surface intermediates—including HCOO, CO, HCO, and CHₓ—suggesting plausible reaction pathways. This work highlights the significant potential of LDH-derived materials as photothermal catalysts for achieving cost-effective, highly stable, selective, and active CO2 conversion, providing valuable insights for developing economically viable and durable photothermal CO2 methanation catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Photothermal technology offers distinct advantages for catalytic CO2 methanation. Herein, we synthesized a series of Ni-based catalysts (denoted as TiO2-x/Ni-X) through controlled calcination of NiTi-layered double hydroxides (LDHs) precursors at 400–700°C. In a continuous-flow system under xenon lamp irradiation (3.2 W/cm²), the TiO2-x /Ni-X catalysts exhibited a reduction temperature dependent CH4 production rate. During 40-hour stability testing, the optimized TiO2-x/Ni-550 catalyst achieved a sustained CH4 production rate of 180 mmol gcat −1 h−1 with a remarkable near-unity selectivity (>99 %), and the light irradiation substantially enhanced the CH4 yield compared to bare thermal catalysis. Comprehensive structural characterization and mechanistic studies revealed competing roles governing catalytic activity, with TiO2-x/Ni-550 demonstrating an optimal balance for CH4 generation kinetics.
